title: Hockey Ballot Blender
text:
Interoperability is the ability of different systems, datasets, or tools to work together seamlessly, whether that means sharing, merging, or analyzing data across different formats or structures.
When we tried to merge everyone‚Äôs award ballots into one dataset, it quickly became clear how important interoperability is. Everyone had different file types, different column names, and different structures. Without a shared format or standard, combining our work became way harder and took way longer than it should have. Interoperability is basically about making systems and datasets able to talk to each other smoothly. If we had agreed on consistent variable names and formats from the start, the merge would‚Äôve been way easier‚Äîand the focus could‚Äôve stayed on the actual analysis, not cleaning up the mess. Definitely a lesson learned for future collab-heavy projects.
In this assignment, I will merge the datasets, then I will be calculating points from the ballots. Since the awards use a ranked voting system simulating the real NHL voting process, each ballot assigns weighted points‚Äîlike 10 for 1st place, 7 for 2nd, and so on. To get a final ranking, we‚Äôll add up the points across everyone‚Äôs submissions.
The player (or nominee) with the highest total number of points across all ballots is the winner. In other words, the one with most consistently high-ranked pick across everyone‚Äôs votes takes the award (?).

clair <- read_csv("Clair_ballots.csv")
john <- read_csv("John_ballots.csv")
marwa <- read_csv("Marwa_ballots.csv")

section: Clean all the tidy/long ones, fix Priya‚Äôs wide format, and merge!
text:
Clean all the tidy/long ones, fix Priya‚Äôs wide format, and merge!


Code
clean_tidy_ballot <- function(df) {
  df %>%
    janitor::clean_names() %>%
    dplyr::rename_with(~ gsub("trophy", "award", ., ignore.case = TRUE)) %>%
    dplyr::rename(
      voter = voter,
      award = award,
      rank = rank,
      player = player
    ) %>%
    dplyr::select(voter, award, rank, player)
}

clean_wide_ballot <- function(df) {
  df %>%
    janitor::clean_names() %>%
    tidyr::pivot_longer(
      cols = -c(voter, rank),
      names_to = "award",
      values_to = "player"
    ) %>%
    dplyr::mutate(rank = as.numeric(rank)) %>%
    dplyr::select(voter, award, rank, player)
}

tidy_names <- c("clair", "john", "marwa", "henry", "ian", "betsy", "barrie", "justice", "sharon")
tidy_cleaned <- lapply(tidy_names, function(name) clean_tidy_ballot(ballots[[name]]))
priya_cleaned <- clean_wide_ballot(ballots$priya)
all_ballots <- dplyr::bind_rows(tidy_cleaned, priya_cleaned)

Code
standardize_award <- function(award) {
  award <- tolower(award)
  award <- gsub("_", " ", award)
  award <- trimws(award)

  case_when(
    str_detect(award, "hart") ~ "Hart Memorial Trophy",
    str_detect(award, "vezina") ~ "Vezina Trophy",
    str_detect(award, "norris") ~ "James Norris Memorial Trophy",
    str_detect(award, "calder") ~ "Calder Memorial Trophy",
    str_detect(award, "selke") ~ "Frank J. Selke Trophy",
    str_detect(award, "lady byng") ~ "Lady Byng Memorial Trophy",
    TRUE ~ str_to_title(award)
  )
}

all_ballots <- all_ballots %>%
  mutate(award = standardize_award(award))

title: Subreddit Wars
text:
In this assignment, I explore how different ways of visualizing data can impact how we understand it. Using the Reddit Hyperlink Network dataset from my previous assignment, I create a series of visualizations to show visualization principles, including expressiveness, effectiveness, discriminability, separability, and popout.
The goal is to show how good design choices make data clearer and easier to interpret, while bad choices can make it confusing or misleading. So, when comparing well designed and poorly designed versions of the same data, I learn what works and what doesn‚Äôt in data visualization.
Code
library(readr)

file_path <- "C:/Github repos/soc-redditHyperlinks-title.tsv"

reddit_data <- read_tsv(file_path)

title: Subreddit Wars
text:
Figure 1:


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

heatmap_data <- reddit_data %>%
  count(SOURCE_SUBREDDIT, TARGET_SUBREDDIT, name = "weight") %>%
  top_n(10, wt = weight) %>%
  arrange(desc(weight))  # ordering from highest to lowest weight


# heatmap
ggplot(heatmap_data, aes(x = SOURCE_SUBREDDIT, y = TARGET_SUBREDDIT, fill = weight)) +
  geom_tile(color = "white") +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "lightblue", high = "darkred") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) +
  labs(title = "Top 10 Subreddit Interactions", 
       x = "Source Subreddit", 
       y = "Target Subreddit", 
       fill = "Link Count")









I‚Äôm making a heatmap to show how subreddits are connected because it helps us easily see their relationships and spot patterns using colors and organization.

The full dataset has tens of thousands of subreddits, but I just focusd here on the top three subreddits by frequency of hyperlinks This figure tracks how subreddits link to each other. Each link has a sentiment: +1 for positive or neutral, -1 for negative. The data spans 2.5 years revealing how subreddits reference, support, or criticize each other.
The positive bar is taller than its negative bar meaning that this community typically links out with positive/neutral sentiment towards other subreddits.

title: Anscombe‚Äôs Quartet Visualization
text:
For this assignment, I‚Äôm doing a visualization with Anscombe‚Äôs Quartet‚Äîa very interesting dataset that shows how important it is to actually see our data, not just look at the stats. It is named after Frank Anscombe, t he one who designed the dataset in 1973 to teach this lesson.
The dataset consists of four groups of x and y values that share almost identical summary statistics (mean, variance, and correlation) but look so different when plotted. I‚Äôll create two visualizations, one straightforward and coded by hand, and another with a little help from AI to make it more playful and polished.

title: Anscombe‚Äôs Quartet Visualization
text:
A nicer cuter one,


Code
ggplot(anscombe_tidy, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = "Data Points"), size = 4, alpha = 0.8, shape = 21, fill = "#80CBC4") +
  geom_smooth(aes(color = "Trend Line"), method = "lm", se = FALSE, size = 1.2, linetype = "dashed") +
  facet_wrap(~set, ncol = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Data Points" = "#4DB6AC", "Trend Line" = "#E57373"),
    name = NULL
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Anscombe's Quartet",
    subtitle = "Identical statistical summaries, visually distinct datasets. Like whaaat! :o",
    x = "X Values",
    y = "Y Values",
    caption = "Data Source: Anscombe (1973)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 18, hjust = 0.5, color = "#37474F"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, hjust = 0.5, color = "#546E7A"),
    strip.text = element_text(face = "bold", color = "#FF7043"),
    axis.title = element_text(face = "bold", color = "#37474F"),
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "#CFD8DC"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#F9FBE7", color = NA),
    legend.position = "top",
    legend.justification = "center",
    legend.box.spacing = unit(0.2, "cm")
  )

title: Data Visualization using Reddit Hyperlink Network
text:
For this assignment, I‚Äôm creating a data visualization using the Reddit Hyperlink Network dataset from Stanford‚Äôs SNAP (source). This dataset tracks how different subreddits are connected through hyperlinks‚Äîbasically, when one subreddit links to another in a post.
I picked the second dataset to analyze subreddit interactions based on title mentions rather than mentions in in posts for simplicity. I‚Äôm using Social Network Analysis (SNA) to explore how communities interact and connect on Reddit. The goal is to visualize these relationships and see patterns in how subreddits reference each other!


Code
library(readr)

file_path <- "C:/Github repos/soc-redditHyperlinks-title.tsv"

# using read_tsv to read the data without needing to decompress it
reddit_data <- read_tsv(file_path, comment = "#")

head(reddit_data)

To understand this, we‚Äôll turn the data into a network (graph) where:
- Each subreddit is a dot (node).
- A line (edge) connects two dots if one subreddit links to another.
To see how different communities are connected and which ones are the most linked or influential.

SOURCE_SUBREDDIT is where the link starts (the subreddit that posted the link).

TARGET_SUBREDDIT is where the link goes (the subreddit being linked to).



Code
library(igraph)

edges <- reddit_data[, c("SOURCE_SUBREDDIT", "TARGET_SUBREDDIT")]

reddit_graph <- graph_from_data_frame(edges, directed = TRUE)

summary(reddit_graph)


IGRAPH 9ce47d5 DN-- 54075 571927 -- 
+ attr: name (v/c)


This tells us: - The network consists of 54,075 subreddits. - There are 571,927 hyperlinks connecting them. - The graph is directed, meaning links have a source and a destination.

Creating a network of the most refrenced subreddits

# Get the top 50 most linked subreddits by in-degree
top_50 <- names(sort(degree(reddit_graph, mode = "in"), decreasing = TRUE))[1:50]

# Create a subgraph with only those subreddits
subreddit_subgraph <- induced_subgraph(reddit_graph, vids = top_50)

# Convert to tidygraph for visualization
library(ggraph)

  geom_edge_link(aes(alpha = 0.5), color = "gray") +
  geom_node_point(size = 5, aes(color = degree(subreddit_subgraph, mode = "in"))) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name), repel = TRUE, size = 4) +
  theme_void() +
  ggtitle("Top 50 Most Linked Subreddits")

title: Hockey Analytics
text:
In this assignment, I will create data driven ballots for 6 NHL awards, ranking five players per category. These awards such as the Hart Memorial Trophy for MVP, the Vezina Trophy for top goaltender, and the Calder Memorial Trophy for best rookie are determined by subjective voting, but my approach will rely on relevant performance metrics.

Reading the data and basic joins and filtering


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(kableExtra)
library(pillar)


base_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ProfessorPolymorphic/BCB520/main/posts/A5-TabularData/"

rookie_goalies      <- read_csv(paste0(base_url, "RookieGoalies.csv"))
rookie_skaters_ind  <- read_csv(paste0(base_url, "RookieSkaterIndividual.csv"))
rookie_skaters_onice<- read_csv(paste0(base_url, "RookieSkaterOnIce.csv"))
skaters_ind         <- read_csv(paste0(base_url, "SkaterIndividualstats.csv"))
skaters_onice       <- read_csv(paste0(base_url, "SkaterOnIcestats.csv"))




Code
all_skaters <- skaters_onice %>%
  inner_join(skaters_ind, by = c("Player", "Team", "Position", "GP"))

rookie_skaters <- rookie_skaters_onice %>%
  inner_join(rookie_skaters_ind, by = c("Player", "Team", "Position", "GP"))




Hart Memorial Trophy
This is for player most valuable to the team. The criteria I will use is total points per game in at least 30 games played.


Code
mvp_candidates <- all_skaters %>%
  filter(GP >= 30) %>%
  mutate(PPG = `Total Points` / GP) %>%
  arrange(desc(PPG)) %>%
  select(Player, Team, Position, GP, `Total Points`, PPG)

#ballot
mvp_top5 <- head(mvp_candidates, 5)




Vezina Trophy
This is for the top goaltender. I will use saves and goals against as metrics.


Code
vezina_candidates <- rookie_goalies %>%
  filter(GP >= 30) %>%
  mutate(SavePercentage = Saves / (Saves + `Goals Against`)) %>%
  arrange(desc(SavePercentage)) %>% 
  select(Player, Team, GP, Saves, `Goals Against`, SavePercentage)

#ballot
vezina_top5 <- head(vezina_candidates, 5)




Calder Memorial Trophy
This is for rookie of the year, the most proficient player in his first year of competition.


Code
calder_candidates <- rookie_skaters %>%
  filter(GP >= 30) %>%
  mutate(PPG = `Total Points` / GP) %>%
  arrange(desc(PPG)) %>%
  select(Player, Team, Position, GP, `Total Points`, PPG)

#ballot
calder_top5 <- head(calder_candidates, 5)




James Norris Memorial Trophy
This is awarded to the defenseman with the greatest all around ability. I will filter by Position == ‚ÄúD‚Äù and use a hypothetical Impact metric, which will be the total of points and assists relative to time on ice.


Code
norris_candidates <- all_skaters %>%
  filter(Position == "D", GP >= 30) %>%
  mutate(Impact = (`Total Points` + `Total Assists`) / TOI.x) %>% 
  arrange(desc(Impact)) %>%
  select(Player, Team, GP, `Total Points`, `Total Assists`, Impact)

#ballot
norris_top5 <- head(norris_candidates, 5)




Frank J. Selke Trophy
This is for the forwards player who best excels in the defensive aspects of the game. I will be using on ice shot for percentage.


Code
selke_candidates <- all_skaters %>%
  filter(Position %in% c("C", "R"), GP >= 30) %>%
  mutate(DefensiveRating = `SF%`) %>%
  arrange(desc(DefensiveRating)) %>%
  select(Player, Team, GP, `Total Points`, `SF%`, DefensiveRating)

selke_top5 <- head(selke_candidates, 5)




Lady Byng Memorial Trophy
This is for the player who has best sportsmanship while also having a high standard of playing. I will use low penalty minutes (PIM) as a proxy for that.


Code
lady_byng_candidates <- all_skaters %>%
  filter(GP >= 30) %>% 
  mutate(Sportsmanship = ifelse(PIM == 0, 1, 1 / PIM)) %>%
  arrange(desc(Sportsmanship)) %>%
  select(Player, Team, GP, PIM, Sportsmanship)

#ballot
lady_byng_top5 <- head(lady_byng_candidates, 5)

Code
library(readxl)
library(tidygraph)
library(ggraph)
library(igraph)
library(dplyr)
Code
file_path <- "Networksfixed.xlsx"

people <- read_excel(file_path, sheet = "People")
relations <- read_excel(file_path, sheet = "Relations")
org_chart <- read_excel(file_path, sheet = "Sheet1")
Code
library(readxl)
library(tidygraph)
library(ggraph)
library(igraph)
library(dplyr)

# Load data
people <- read_excel("Networksfixed.xlsx", sheet = "People")
relations <- read_excel("Networksfixed.xlsx", sheet = "Relations")

# Create network
graph <- tbl_graph(nodes = people, edges = relations, directed = TRUE)

# Plot network
ggraph(graph, layout = "fr") +
  geom_edge_link(aes(color = Advisor), alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_node_point(aes(color = department), size = 4) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name), repel = TRUE, size = 3) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(title = "Network of People & Advisor Relationships",
       subtitle = "Edge color = Advisor, Node color = Department")
